issue.title: disable pthreads testing for mem test
issue.body:
Implementation (preparation) for #439 (see discussion there) reusing existing test code.

@xvzcf , @dstebila : Please (re)confirm that `test_kem`/`test_sig` do not do more testing than desirable when setting the new `-mem` option.

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding or removing?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

comment.body: For lines 84-143, there are still some unnecessary operations happening depending on the mode.  For example, if op=KEM\_KEYGEN, the ciphertext and shared secret memory is still allocated (lines 86-88), and still loaded from disk (lines 123-124).  Can we just make it one big switch statement with only the lines for the operation present?  There may be a little bit of duplication of code but we can be sure we're only allocating exactly the memory needed.

issue.title: Current "main" branch: tests hang in test_free()
issue.body:
MacOS Catalina 10.15.7, Xcode-12.2.

Config:
```
env RUN_TESTS_PARALLEL_UPPER=FALSE cmake -GNinja .. -DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=ON -DOQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS=ON -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=OFF -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/opt/local -DOQS_KEM_DEFAULT="OQS_KEM_alg_ntru_hps4096821" -DOQS_SIG_DEFAULT="OQS_SIG_alg_falcon_1024" -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
```

Run tests:

comment.body:
Here's my test-script:
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import sys
import subprocess

def test_free():
    files = subprocess.Popen(["find", "src/common/", "-name", "*.c"], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, encoding="utf8")
    try: 
        fouts,ferrs = files.communicate(timeout=10)
    except TimeoutExpired:
        files.kill()
        fouts,ferrs = files.communicate()
    #files.terminate()
    files.stdout.close()
    fliles = subprocess.Popen(["grep", "-v", "picnic/external"], stdin=subprocess.PIPE, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, encoding="utf8")
    try: 
        flouts,flerrs = fliles.communicate(input=fouts, timeout=10)
    except TimeoutExpired:
        fliles.kill()
        flouts,flerrs = fliles.communicate()
    #fliles.terminate()
    fliles.stdout.close()
    llines  = subprocess.Popen(["grep", "[^_]free("], stdin=subprocess.PIPE, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, encoding="utf8")
    try: 
        louts,lerrs = llines.communicate(input=flouts, timeout=18)
        print("llines returncode = ", llines.returncode)
        print("flouts=")
        print(flouts)
    except TimeoutExpired:
        llines.kill()
        louts,lerrs = llines.communicate()
    llines.terminate()
    print("louts=")
    print(louts)
    lines = louts.split("\n")
    print("lines=")
    print(lines)
    okay = True
    for line in lines:
        if line == "": continue
        if not('IGNORE free-check' in line):
            okay = False
            print("Suspicious `free` in " + line)
    assert okay, "'free' is used in some files.  These should be changed to 'OQS_MEM_secure_free' or 'OQS_MEM_insecure_free' as appropriate. If you are sure you want to use 'free' in a particular spot, add the comment '// IGNORE free-check' on the line where 'free' occurs."

if __name__ == "__main__":
    test_free()
```

Here's it's output:
```
$ ./t.py
llines returncode =  1
flouts=
src/common/common.c
src/common/sha2/sha2_c.c
src/common/sha2/sha2_ossl.c
src/common/sha3/sha3_c.c
src/common/sha3/sp800-185.c
src/common/sha3/sha3_ossl.c
src/common/sha3/sha3x4.c
src/common/sha3/fips202.c
src/common/sha3/keccak4x/KeccakP-1600-times4-SIMD256.c
src/common/pqclean_shims/nistseedexpander.c
src/common/rand/rand_nist.c
src/common/rand/rand.c
src/common/aes/aes256_ni.c
src/common/aes/aes.c
src/common/aes/aes128_ni.c
src/common/aes/aes_c.c
src/common/aes/aes_ossl.c

louts=

lines=
['']
```

It appears that the last `grep` subprocess somehow fails. Any idea how to track this down?

comment.body:
Thank you!

Corrected file:
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import sys
import subprocess

def test_free():
    files = subprocess.Popen(["find", "src/common/", "-name", "*.c"], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, encoding="utf8")
    try: 
        fouts,ferrs = files.communicate(timeout=10)
    except TimeoutExpired:
        files.kill()
        fouts,ferrs = files.communicate()
    files.stdout.close()
    fliles = subprocess.Popen(["grep", "-v", "picnic/external"], stdin=subprocess.PIPE, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, encoding="utf8")
    try: 
        flouts,flerrs = fliles.communicate(input=fouts, timeout=10)
    except TimeoutExpired:
        fliles.kill()
        flouts,flerrs = fliles.communicate()
    fliles.stdout.close()
    llines  = subprocess.Popen(["xargs", "grep", "[^_]free("], stdin=subprocess.PIPE, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, encoding="utf8")
    try: 
        louts,lerrs = llines.communicate(input=flouts, timeout=18)
    except TimeoutExpired:
        llines.kill()
        louts,lerrs = llines.communicate()
    llines.stdout.close()
    lines = louts.split("\n")
    okay = True
    for line in lines:
        if line == "": continue
        if not('IGNORE free-check' in line):
            okay = False
            print("Suspicious `free` in " + line)
    assert okay, "'free' is used in some files.  These should be changed to 'OQS_MEM_secure_free' or 'OQS_MEM_insecure_free' as appropriate. If you are sure you want to use 'free' in a particular spot, add the comment '// IGNORE free-check' on the line where 'free' occurs."

if __name__ == "__main__":
    test_free()
```

Output on modified `src/common/common.c` (changed one `IGNORE` to `GNORE`):
```
$ ./t.py
Suspicious `free` in src/common/common.c:		free(ptr); // GNORE free-check
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./t.py", line 38, in <module>
    test_free()
  File "./t.py", line 35, in test_free
    assert okay, "'free' is used in some files.  These should be changed to 'OQS_MEM_secure_free' or 'OQS_MEM_insecure_free' as appropriate. If you are sure you want to use 'free' in a particular spot, add the comment '// IGNORE free-check' on the line where 'free' occurs."
AssertionError: 'free' is used in some files.  These should be changed to 'OQS_MEM_secure_free' or 'OQS_MEM_insecure_free' as appropriate. If you are sure you want to use 'free' in a particular spot, add the comment '// IGNORE free-check' on the line where 'free' occurs.
```

Output on corrected `src/common/*.c`:
```
$ ./t.py
$ 
```

issue.title: How to set the new algorithms when building on Windows 10
issue.body:
Does nmake generate_crypto_objects work well when working on Windows 10? Or what is the other building alternative?

Thank you!

comment.body:
A quick report:
Rainbow Vc Cyclic/Classic, Classic Mc-Eliece and sidhp751 seem not to work on Windows. (Especially Classic - McEliece is not working on both Linux/Win builds)

issue.title: How to set the new algorithms when building on Windows 10
issue.body:
Does nmake generate_crypto_objects work well when working on Windows 10? Or what is the other building alternative?

Thank you!

comment.body: Could you please be more specific? What exactly is not working? Steps to reproduce (for starters in Linux)?

issue.title: How to set the new algorithms when building on Windows 10
issue.body:
Does nmake generate_crypto_objects work well when working on Windows 10? Or what is the other building alternative?

Thank you!

comment.body:
Michael,
All seem to can be built normally, but, sidhp751 provides a segmentatior - memory fault when launched on Windows 10 as client (with Ubuntu as Server) but works normally on Linux - Linux tunnels.
(I use OQS for tunnel - testing purposes based on Microsoft's PQCrypto-VPN)

Classic - McEliece is already known not to function as a tunnel KEM prior an according alteration to the OpenSSL and/or OpenVPN protocol source is made but to overflow or something like this.

Rainbow Vc Classic / Cyclic keys after some updates to their algorithm or so, can not be produced on the Windows buils, but can normally be generated on Ubuntu builds.

Any possible clues and information on this report will be much appreciated!

Thank you for your work!

issue.title: How to set the new algorithms when building on Windows 10
issue.body:
Does nmake generate_crypto_objects work well when working on Windows 10? Or what is the other building alternative?

Thank you!

comment.body: I'm still not sure I can follow: Can you reproduce the problem using only OQS-OpenSSL or does this only happen when using OpenVPN?

issue.title: disable pthreads testing for mem test
issue.body:
Implementation (preparation) for #439 (see discussion there) reusing existing test code.

@xvzcf , @dstebila : Please (re)confirm that `test_kem`/`test_sig` do not do more testing than desirable when setting the new `-mem` option.

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding or removing?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

comment.body: Agree: Makes things more correct. Code suitably amended. SIG support also added.

issue.title: How to set the new algorithms when building on Windows 10
issue.body:
Does nmake generate_crypto_objects work well when working on Windows 10? Or what is the other building alternative?

Thank you!

comment.body:
Michael,
They seem to be OpenVPN only-occuring issues, since all liboqs and oqs-openssl tests are passed on build.

issue.title: How to set the new algorithms when building on Windows 10
issue.body:
Does nmake generate_crypto_objects work well when working on Windows 10? Or what is the other building alternative?

Thank you!

comment.body: Wouldn't it be better then to raise an issue with the OQS-OpenVPN team/git and close this topic here? Sorry that I don't have enough experience with OpenVPN than to suggest that... @christianpaquin : Do you have another suggestion?

issue.title: How to set the new algorithms when building on Windows 10
issue.body:
Does nmake generate_crypto_objects work well when working on Windows 10? Or what is the other building alternative?

Thank you!

comment.body:
Michael,
You are right, will stick to them and check further!
Thank you all for your great work.

Best regards

issue.title: disable pthreads testing for mem test
issue.body:
Implementation (preparation) for #439 (see discussion there) reusing existing test code.

@xvzcf , @dstebila : Please (re)confirm that `test_kem`/`test_sig` do not do more testing than desirable when setting the new `-mem` option.

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding or removing?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

comment.body: Replaced by #854

> Did you actually see the timeout triggered in the tests on your machine?

Thankfully, no. I put them there just to make sure it finishes on its own. 

Theoretically, one can remove that argument altogether. But, given my experience, I'd prefer to set them to something large enough to work on the expected platforms, but saving the run from a hangup like what I've seen.
